text: Hey, what's up guys? Welcome back to Binging with Babish.
Where, this week, I'm going to mispronounce a lot of things like this,
"kombu", which kind of looks like green lasagna noodles.
It helps to form the soup base for Tampopo-style Shoyu ramen
Along with about a pound of chicken feet, whose nails were going to snip off before getting a large stoc-oop
A large stock pot ready, with a quarter pound of pork spare ribs and two pounds of chicken wings.
We're going to add that to the pot with our chicken feet, a whole head of garlic, halved,
one large scallion, cut into 6 inch pieces,
a whole onion, halved,
and about four quarts of water, in which we've soaked
four large kombu leaves for about 24 hours.
We're going to put this over very low heat,
and bring to a bare simmer, skimming off any scum that comes to the top
and keeping it below 200 degrees Fahrenheit.
After about four hours, we're going to add some bonito
and some dried anchovies, which we're going to strain after about another hour.
Chill that broth overnight while we make our noodles.
We need to bake some baking soda at 225 degrees Fahrenheit for about an hour
before dissolving one tablespoon in half a cup of warm water that we're going to slowly drizzle
into eight and a half ounces of bread flour, along with one ounce of vital wheat gluten.
Press together into a shaggy dough and knead for about five minutes
before letting it rest in plastic wrap for one hour.
Rolling it out using a pasta machine.
Roll it thinner and thinner until you can run it through the pasta cutter.
Creating perfect little alkaline noodles that we're going to toss with cornstarch,
place on a baking sheet, cover in plastic wrap, and refrigerate overnight.
Now yes,
You could chemically alter your own baking soda
and create noodles that take several hours to make before refrigerating for 24 hours
Or you could just buy a packet at the store.
They're not gonna be nearly as good, but I don't know your call.
Moving on, it's time to make our Chashu pork.
Now, I wasn't sure if it was pork belly or pork shoulder, so I went ahead and got both.
I'm gonna start by searing the pork shoulder
while leaving the pork belly unaffected before topping with
half a cup of soy sauce,
a full cup of mirin, a type of Japanese cooking wine,
a full cup of sake.
By the way mix this stuff up beforehand,
don't do it like I'm doing.
One whole shallot halved,
A two-inch knob of ginger, peeled and chopped,
and half a dozen cloves of crushed garlic
Now, we're going to top this, but leave the lid slightly ajar,
and braise at 275 for about three hours.
Now, in the same pan in which we seared the pork
we're going to saute half a cup of dried anchovies,
before deglazing with two cups of soy sauce,
adding a couple broken kombu leaves,
letting that steep without boiling for about ten minutes,
adding half a cup of bonito flake,
and letting that steep and additional five minutes before draining and setting aside.
Wipe out the pan and add about a quarter cup of sake,
a few tablespoons of mirin,
and one to two tablespoons brown sugar.
We're going to bring that to a boil and burn off the alcohol
Before adding our fishy soy sauce mixture back to the party and boom we've got "tare".
Now, finally, it's time to assemble.
While we boil our noodles for no more than 30 seconds, place two tablespoons of "tare",
half a tablespoon of toasted sesame oil,
a few ladlefuls of our broth, boiling hot,
and finally our noodles, into a warm bowl.
Then we're going to garnish with three very thin slices of our pork,
a slice of "kamaboko" or Japanese fish cake,
a few scallions,
some "menma", or braised Bamboo shoots,
and our sheet of "nori", or seaweed
Now, it's time to lovingly stroke our pork and apologize to it.
Move it over to the side of the bowl, as the ramen master did,
and begin slurping your noodles.
It's very important to slurp the noodles,
both to attain maximum flavor,
and to embarrass yourself in front of friends and family.
